{{main|Crime in Egypt}}
[[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref> The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mr. Mubarakâs ruling party, ''Baltageya'' ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{Cite news|author=David KirkpAtrick|coauthors=Kareem Fahim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=03 February 2011| accessdate=03 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: liberalism, Islam, and democracy in the Arab world|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> In 2010, [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref> The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mr. Mubarakâs ruling party, ''Baltageya'' ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{Cite news|author=David KirkpAtrick|coauthors=Kareem Fahim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=03 February 2011| accessdate=03 February 2011}}</ref>
